Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps L: SENSE IT - The Student Enabled Network of Sensors for the Environment using Innovative Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the NSF Innovations Corps for Learning Program (I-Corps L), this project will develop ways to increase the scale and impact of an instructional system to help teachers and students to create and use sensors to measure water quality. Sensors surround us and increasingly add information and guidance to our lives; however, many people are not aware of this or specifically how sensors work. The Student Enabled Network of Sensors for the Environment using Innovative Technology (SENSE IT) program provides an opportunity for teachers and students to learn core science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) knowledge through building, testing, programming, and deploying their own water quality sensor networks. There are other STEM programs that focus on the use of sensors; however, SENSE IT is distinctive in that the instruction covers design concepts, construction, calibration, and programming of the sensor as well as deployment and use. The project prepares and motivates young people for the future STEM workforce by providing: 1) a motivating, meaningful, and hands-on scenario for learning a wide range of STEM topics, 2) an engaging link between biological, physical, and social sciences, and 3) a cutting-edge example of science and engineering research, delivered directly into the classroom.

The I-Corps for Learning project will increase the accessibly and widespread use of the existing SENSE IT program. The project will address the manufacturing and distribution of sensor kits (temperature, conductivity, turbidity, and depth) to provide easy access to the required materials to construct the sensors. Additional effort will involve providing access to the online curriculum and online professional development to provide teachers with the subject matter expertise to successfully lead students through the sensor construction, calibration, and deployment process. With the implementation of the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) infusing engineering into science classes and increasingly popular Maker and other DIY movements across the country, SENSE IT will serve as a model for fully integrated STEM experiences addressing NGSS with interchangeable technology resources. If successful, a fully virtual professional development format will reach teachers who cannot travel or cannot get leave time from school, representing a expansion of available professional development programs. Through these accomplishments, SENSE IT will create a lower cost, and more widely accessible, hands-on STEM educational experience, contributing to the democratization of 21st century STEM education opportunities and expanding the number of students interested in and prepared for STEM related careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Student Enabled Network of Sensors for the Environment using Innovative Technology (SENSE IT - http://www.senseit.org/) project leads students through sensor construction, the programming necessary to calibrate the sensors, developing a wireless sensor network, and finally deployment of their own sensors in the environment. SENSE IT requires the development and use of an interdisciplinary set of skills including: science, technology, pre-engineering, mathematics (STEM) and general workforce competencies, which are transferable to a wide spectrum of STEM careers and preparation for the 21st century workforce.

 

Sensors surround us and increasingly add information and guidance to our lives; however, many are not aware of this or specifically how sensor work. SENSE IT leads students through the construction process, and also an understanding of the increasing importance of sensors in our world. Independent evaluation results showed gains in learning for the three key aspects of sensor building that were assessed: understanding of electricity, core math skills, and programming skills. Learning gains were particularly significant for students from low socio-economic (SES) districts. Results showed a significant narrowing of the gap between previously low- and high-achieving students, and between students from low- and high-SES districts. SENSE IT stimulated interest in, and enhanced practical understanding of STEM subjects.

 

However, three obstacles emerged which are hampering larger scale implementation of the project. The first is the inability of teachers to easily assemble the required materials, the second is the cost of materials, and the third is that many teachers lack the required subject matter expertise. 

 

To address materials acquisition, we will construct kits and making them available for purchase by teachers, schools districts and informal groups. Kits will contain the materials required to construct a specific sensor (temperature, conductivity, turbidity and depth). To address cost, we would purchase materials in bulk, lowering the total costs incurred by a single teacher assembling materials; we investigated lower-cost options for the microprocessor required for sensor calibration, data logging and communications.  To increase teacher’s confidence with the curriculum we will offer on-line training on demand as a subscription service. 

 

With the implementation of the Next Generation Science Standards infusing engineering into science classes and increasingly popular Maker and other DIY movements across the country, we believe there is a strong potential for sales of SENSE IT kit, coupled with the curriculum. We are currently coaching schools through the process of materials acquisition for free, simply to see the curriculum used.

 

The application and acceptance to the ICorp-L program allowed the SENSE IT team to investigate options for kit construction, packaging and marketing based on data gathered through interviews with teachers, administrators and informal education program leaders.

 

As a result of participation in ICorp-L, the SENSE IT team will create a plan for scalability and build the footing for sustainability of the SENSE IT program in educational settings across the U.S.  The project will expand the effective practices identified from the evaluation data from the original ITEST grant-funded work and ICorp-L work. The goal is to expand the reach of SENSE IT from 3,000 students as of today to over 100,000 annually.

SENSE IT will serve as a model for fully integrated STEM classroom experiences addressing NGSS with interchangeable technology resources. If successful, a fully virtual PD format will reach teachers who cannot travel and/or cannot get leave time from school, representing a substantial expansion beyond previous programs. Through these accomplishments, SENSE IT will create a lower cost, and more widely accessible, hands-on STEM educational experience, contributing to the democratization of 21st century STEM education opportunities and expanding the number of students interested in and prepared for STEM related careers.
